cleaned_text: it is commonly known today 'plasma therapy', is one of the few options considered in the treatment of Covid-19 patients. With the second wave spreading rapidly across all parts of the country, here's your complete guide to understanding this treatment method. What You Should Know: What is plasma therapy? This method of treatment requires the blood sample of a person who has recovered from Coronavirus. The next step is extracting the antibodies from the blood sample and transfusing them into the system of a patient infected with the virus. The aim of this treatment is to kickstart the immune system of the patient to fight the virus. How effective is plasma therapy for Covid-19? Plasma therapy has been used as an alternative treatment for critical Covid-19 patients. It is especially effective in patients suffering from liver dysfunction or diabetes. However, it will not be helpful in treating any patient with the new Covid-19 triple mutation strain discovered in India. The All India Institute Of Medical Sciences (AIIMS) chief, Dr Randeep Guleria, also recently stated that plasma therapy plays a limited role in the treatment and is not used often. Who can be a plasma donor? Plasma therapy can still be a helpful treatment option for patients. Especially in the current scenario, where the healthcare system is stretched to its limit. Here's how to find out if you can become a plasma donor and potentially save some lives: - You need to have recovered from the Covid-19 and tested negative for the virus - You must have shown no symptoms of the virus for the past 14 days. - It's important to have high antibody levels in your plasma - Your blood type must be compatible with the patient. Once you donate your plasma, it will be tested for other infectious diseases before being used to treat a patient.
